name: Glycine
summary: Glycine is a non-essential amino acid that functions as both a neurotransmitter and a metabolic regulator, studied for its roles in sleep, cognition, metabolic health, and adjunctive psychiatric treatment.
description: Glycine is the simplest amino acid and serves as a key building block for proteins, glutathione, creatine, and collagen. In the central nervous system, it functions as both an inhibitory neurotransmitter (especially in the spinal cord and brainstem) and as a co-agonist at NMDA receptors, modulating glutamatergic transmission. Supplemental glycine has been studied for improving sleep quality, reducing core body temperature before sleep, enhancing cognitive function, and as an adjunctive treatment in schizophrenia and other psychiatric disorders. It also plays roles in metabolic regulation, stress response, and antioxidant defense.

metadata.natural_source: Protein-rich foods, gelatin, collagen, bone broth
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for medical indications)

monitoring_required: Cognitive and psychiatric status in high-dose use

items: Investigated as an adjunct in schizophrenia and OCD

sections.text: Glycine acts as an inhibitory neurotransmitter in the spinal cord and brainstem while also functioning as a co-agonist at NMDA receptors in the brain, influencing excitatory glutamatergic signaling. By reducing core body temperature and modulating sleep-wake cycles, glycine can improve subjective and objective sleep quality. Its role in glutathione synthesis contributes to antioxidant defense and metabolic regulation.

adult.typical: 3 g orally at bedtime for sleep; 10–60 g/day in divided doses studied in schizophrenia (clinical supervision required)
adult.note: Lower doses (1–5 g) commonly used for sleep and relaxation.

sections.pediatric: Limited data; not routinely recommended outside clinical trials.

sections.text: Sleep benefits typically observed within days; psychiatric effects require weeks of sustained high-dose therapy in clinical trials.

serious: Electrolyte imbalance and renal strain at very high doses

other: High-dose use (>30 g/day) should only be undertaken under medical supervision.
May interact with antipsychotic treatment response.

sections.geriatrics: Generally safe at low doses; monitor renal function

sections.text: No taper required; may discontinue without withdrawal effects.

items: At bedtime doses (~3 g), glycine improves subjective sleep quality and next-day performance.
High-dose glycine has been trialed as an adjunct in schizophrenia, though results are mixed.
Acts as both inhibitory neurotransmitter and NMDA co-agonist, providing a dual role in CNS regulation.
